Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Andrew J. Manion is "Knot Homology Theories and Quantum Representations." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Ciprian Manolescu.

POR.DRECONTENT:
From 2015-2018, the PI was funded by an NSF postdoctoral research fellowship in mathematics (MSPRF). The funded research centered around Heegaard Floer homology and its connections to other mathematical constructions, especially Khovanov homology and categorified representation theory. 

Heegaard Floer homology and Khovanov homology are modern sets of invariants for low-dimensional manifolds and knots. They have different origins; Heegaard Floer homology is a symplectic variant of gauge-theoretic constructions with close links to the physics of supersymmetric Yang-Mills quantum field theories in four dimensions. Defining and computing Heegaard Floer homology typically requires hard analysis. Khovanov homology, on the other hand, has an elementary and algorithmic definition, requiring no analysis at all; it is also related to physics via ``categorified'' versions of three-dimensional Chern-Simons quantum field theories. Khovanov homology also fits into a rich algebraic framework centered around categorified representations of quantum groups, with links to geometric constructions such as perverse sheaves on partial flag varieties.

The research resulted in three journal articles and four preprints posted after July 2018 but built on work that was done during the funded period. One of these preprints has been accepted for publication. Below we describe these results and an ongoing project initiated under NSF support.

(a) In the past decade, bordered Floer homology has been a powerful tool for algebraicizing Heegaard Floer homology. One potential source of connections to Khovanov homology could come from Khovanov theories with the same algebraic structure as bordered Floer homology. The PI studied one such theory, due to Roberts, and related it to an earlier ``arc algebra'' construction of Khovanov with close links to geometric categorification.

(b) Ozsvath-Szabo introduced a bordered variant of Heegaard Floer homology for knots (HFK) in 2016, giving HFK an algorithmic definition that is amenable to fast computer calculation. The PI showed that Ozsvath-Szabo's theory categorifies tangle maps coming from the representation theory of the quantum deformation of the Lie superalgebra gl(1|1). It had previously been known that Khovanov's arc algebra categorifies similar maps coming from sl(2), helping to explain similarities and differences between Ozsvath-Szabo's and Khovanov's theories.

(c) Other constructions have been given to categorify quantum gl(1|1) representations and intertwining maps; one such construction, due to Sartori, has connections to category O and geometric representation theory analogous to those of Khovanov's arc algebra. One piece of Sartori's construction is easier to understand, and was described earlier by Khovanov-Seidel. The PI showed that the algebras in this piece of Sartori's construction are quotients of Ozsvath-Szabo's algebras, and that the bimodules on each side have a corresponding relationship.

(d) Ozsvath-Szabo's bordered theory arises from a certain Heegaard diagram (the ``Kauffman-states diagram''), to which a local version of holomorphic disk counts is applied. Another Heegaard diagram, the ``planar diagram,'' has also been used to prove recent impressive results in Heegaard Floer homology, so one would like to have a bordered theory for the planar diagram. This would be most plausible if one could cut the planar diagram into local pieces that are transformable into Ozsvath-Szabo's local pieces for the Kauffman-states diagram. The PI constructed such a decomposition of the planar diagram, making essential use of a small tweak of the Kauffman-states diagram introduced for analytic reasons by Ozsvath-Szabo.

(e) While Ozsvath-Szabo's new bordered algebras are not among the previously-existing algebras in bordered Floer homology, Marengon, Willis, and the PI showed that they are quasi-isomorphic to certain reasonable generalizations of these algebras. The proof relied on the results of a separate preprint giving an alternate algebraic description of Ozsvath-Szabo's algebras and determining their formality (or lack thereof in many cases) as dg algebras. These results may lead to a deeper understanding of Ozsvath-Szabo's algebras in terms of Fukaya categories, known to be related to bordered algebras by work of Auroux.

(f) Algebraic theories like Khovanov homology assign bimodules or functors to trivalent webs, not just tangles. The PI defined an explicit A-infinity bimodule for a ``thick edge'' in Ozsvath-Szabo's theory. The bimodule arises heuristically from holomorphic disk counts in a generalized Kauffman-states diagram defined earlier by Ozsvath-Stipsicz-Szabo.

(g) Higher representation theory is a powerful way to understand algebraic theories. However, there is a crucial tensor product operation for higher representations that is currently missing in the literature. It has been developed in significant generality in unpublished work of Rouquier. For gl(1|1) (in preparation), Rouquier and the PI construct the tensor product and relate it to earlier work of Douglas--Manolescu in cornered Floer homology, a somewhat-mysterious ``doubly-local'' variant of bordered Floer homology.

During the duration of NSF funding, the PI mentored two undergraduate students in independent projects and co-organized a semester-long graduate student seminar on bordered Floer homology. The PI gave lectures at conferences and seminars both in the US and abroad.
